nodes.bodyText: We should throw exception here? Or it throws exception we need to handle?

I checked the code, "return null" won't cause an exception to be thrown. The zkclient won't set null to zk, and accessor will return a boolean[] for updateChildren, where it returns false for the node whose updater returns null. If you think throw exception is a better way to handle it, I can change it too.
This is the assumption, if the current data does not exist, return null. I think it is fine.
Did you miss some files here? MessageQueueMonitor does not have such a constructor and it is not changed in this PR.

In general, passing the manager to the monitor object would be an overkill. If it is really necessary, then we shall change the constructor to accept the manager only, since it includes all the information.
If you always return msg.getRecord() why not just set? You are not updating the currentData anyway.
I use the updater here to check if the current data exists, if not then don't set the new data. And if there is current data, then just set the new data, that's why I'm not updating currentData here.
I see, could you please comment the reason here?
Nevermind, I see you already noted it down above.

Why? The periodic refresh does not need to be done synchronized, I think.
If your timer action just adds the refresh event to the queue, there is no need to modify this.

Why do you need to call it here synchronously? I think it's simpler if we just put this event into the event queue.
Given this saying, this logic will be fitting better if it is in the HelixManager level. What I'm trying to propose if the HelixManger is initialized as a Participant, then we start this timer thread there. It just injects message event with a certain interval. Of course, if a real message event comes earlier, then we reset the timer.
Put this logic in the executor does not make sense to me.
@jiajunwang I have added the logging. Can you please check if the message is good?
One optimization here maybe to create just one updater instead of one per each message. You can define the update logic in the updater, i.e, read the message and mark the read field as "read".
